attributes.description: "This alert triggers when global permission is defined on a range of ports, grants access to one or more administrative ports, and is detected in a security group."
attributes.name: Administrative Ports Security Group
attributes.resolution: "Generally, it is not advisable to permit access to administrative ports due to the inherent risk of constant enumeration and attack. If you must permit other applications to be accessed by any IP on the internet, please suppress this alert to silence it.For more information, see AWS: Client Ports."

attributes.description: "This alert triggers when global permission to access all ports (IpProtocol -1) is detected in a security group."
attributes.name: Alert IpProtocol -1 on Security Group
attributes.resolution: "This alert triggers when global permission to access all ports (IpProtocol -1) is detected in a security group. This is dangerous. The best security practice dictates restricting access to service ports solely to known static IP addresses within your control.To remediate this alert, you must reduce the security group access list to contain only known hosts, services, employees, or office static IP addresses is advised. For more information, see AWS: Authorizing Inbound Traffic for Your Linux Instances - Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud."

attributes.description: "AWS EC2 Classic is in use, not virtual private clouds (VPCs). AWS has two types of infrastructure containers. The original AWS infrastructure is called EC2 Classic. VPC is the newer, second-generation of AWS infrastructure.Deploying VPCs will enable theyou to leverage enhanced infrastructure security controls.Note: This alert only triggers in regions that support launching into AWS Classic."
attributes.name: AWS Classic is Deployed Instead of VPCs
attributes.resolution: "Move resources into VPCs and disable EC2 Classic in the region to prevent further use.Learn more about creating and configuring VPCs in the AWS VPC User Guide."

attributes.description: "The AWS account is not currently leveraging any CloudFront distributions. CloudFront provides scalable, distributed, and inexpensive Content Distribution Network (CDN) within AWS. Using a content delivery network (CDN) can provide a layer of security between your origin content and its destination. CDNs can ensure consistent delivery of content during a distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack or unexpected increase in traffic volume by providing you time to scale infrastructure to meet traffic demands or helping to identify the origin and mitigate the risk of an attack."
attributes.name: AWS CloudFront CDN Not in Use
attributes.resolution: "Deploy AWS CloudFront using the AWS Management Console. CloudFront provides a scalable, distributed, and inexpensive CDN within AWS. Click here for more information about implementing AWS CloudFront."

attributes.description: "The resource-viewing service AWS Config is not enabled for this AWS account. The AWS Config service provides visibility to user configuration history and configuration change notifications. Along with use of CloudTrail, we consider enabling AWS Config to be a best practice for users."
attributes.name: AWS Config is not enabled
attributes.resolution: "Follow the instructions for enabling AWS Config here."

attributes.description: "A CloudFormation stack is not configured to notify of status and changes. CloudFormation is a useful automation tool, but it is important to stay on top of the activities of all CloudFormation stacks. Use Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS) to be notified of changes and status."
attributes.name: CloudFormation stack configured without SNS topics
attributes.resolution: "Create a notification path using SNS.Log into the AWS Management Console. Navigate to the CloudFormation service.In CloudFormation, select the affected stack and click Actions.Select Update Stack and follow the prompts until the Options page comes up.Modify the appropriate notification options to create a new SNS topic or select a pre-existing topic.Configure so that key staff are able to stay up to date on the CloudFormation behavior."

attributes.description: "CloudTrail should be enabled to keep up visibility in all of your AWS resources. This will assist with forensic analysis, auditing, and compliance."
attributes.name: CloudTrail audit logging not enabled for region
attributes.resolution: "To be as secure and auditable as possible, AWS accounts should always enable CloudTrail. CloudTrail offers an API audit-logging capability to AWS users. To maintain consistent best practices, enable It for every account and region. After logging into the AWS Management Console, follow these steps: Choose CloudTrail from the services list.Click Get Started. You will have the choice of using an existing or creating a new S3 bucket destination for the audit logs.Click Advanced.From the list, choose additional options.Click Subscribe."

attributes.description: "CloudTrail should be configured to use server side encryption (SSE) and key management service (KMS). CloudTrail configured to use SSE-KMS provides additional confidentiality controls on log data. To gain access, users must have S3 read permission on the corresponding log bucket and must be granted decrypt permission by the customer-created master keys (CMK) policy."
attributes.name: CloudTrail log not properly encrypted with SSE-KMS
attributes.resolution: "To configure CloudTrail to use SSE-KMS, follow these steps:Open the CloudTrail console.In the left-hand navigation pane, click Trails.Select a specific trail in section 3 section and click Edit (pencil icon).From the KMS key ID drop-down, select an existing CMK. Click Save.You will see a notification message indicating that to decrypt log files, you will need decrypt permissions are required for the specified KMS key. Click Yes.Note: Be sure the CMK is located in the same region as the S3 bucket. Apply a KMS key policy on the selected CMK. This will enable CloudTrail as-a-service to encrypt and decrypt log files using the CMK provided. "

attributes.description: "CloudTrail logs are not automatically sent to CloudWatch Logs. This signature will facilitate real-time and historic activity logging based on user, API, resource, and IP address. It will also establish alarms and notifications for anomalous or sensitive account activity. The signature generates an alert for any incidents that violate this best security practice."
attributes.name: CloudTrail logs not integrated with CloudWatch
attributes.resolution: "Create this alert to enable log file integration, follow these steps using the AWS Management Console:Sign in to the AWS Management Console.Open the CloudTrail Console.In the left menu, click Trails. In the drop down list, click on each trail where no CloudWatch Logs are defined.Click Save.Navigate to the CloudWatch Logs page, click on Configure. From the list, select an existing log group or define a new one in the field provided.Click Continue.Users should also configure an Identity and Access Management (IAM) Role that will deliver CloudTrail events to CloudWatch logs. In the AWS Management Console, select your chosen IAM Role and create a Policy Name for it. Click Allow to integrate CoudTrail events with CloudWatch logs.For more information, see AWS: CloudTrail Monitoring."

attributes.description: "Customer-managed key management service (KMS) keys are not in use. To provide more granular control of your data encryption, we recommend using customer-managed KMS keys instead of AWS-managed KMS keys."
attributes.name: Customer-Managed Keys Not in Use
attributes.resolution: "To resolve this issue, create customer-managed KMS keys and use them for encrypting and decrypting data in the AWS Management Console.For specific instructions, see the AWS: Editing Encryption Keys section of the AWS Developer Guide."

attributes.description: "Elastic Block Store (EBS) volumes do not have volume encryption enabled. EBS volume encryption is a powerful capability that will help protect your data at rest on an EBS volume."
attributes.name: EBS Volume Encryption Not Enabled
attributes.resolution: "To enable EBS volume encryption, you need to create a new, encrypted EBS volume and migrate the old data to the new volume. Learn more about this process in the AWS EBS documentation."

attributes.description: "Customer-managed key management service (KMS) keys are not in use. To provide more granular control of your data encryption, we recommend using customer-managed KMS keys instead of AWS-managed KMS keys."
attributes.name: EBS Volume not Encrypted with Customer Managed Key
attributes.resolution: "To resolve this issue, create customer-managed KMS keys and use them for encrypting and decrypting data in the AWS Management Console.For specific instructions, see the Editing Keys section of the AWS Developer Guide."

attributes.description: "Elastic block store (EBS) volumes have no snapshots in recent, 15-day history. These are needed to retain critical system data, security logs, and system state.EBS volume snapshots are an important tool to record system state, security log data, and critical system data at various points in your EC2 instance lifecycle. Snapshots provide point-in-time recovery and review capability that is necessary for many operational and security practices."
attributes.name: EBS Volumes Does Not Have Recent Snapshot
attributes.resolution: "To resolve this issue, you can take \"hot\" snapshots which do not require un-mounting EBS volumes. Another option involves taking standard snapshots which require you to unmount the volume and then snapshot it prior to re-attaching it.For step-by-step instructions on creating EBS volume snapshots, click here."

attributes.description: "Distributed API keys to EC2 Instances is a dangerous practice and should be avoided wherever possible.AWS provides native support for enabling EC2 Instance to Service Communication using a secure, authenticated method called Individual Access Management (IAM) Roles. IAM Roles offer AWS users a way to create a role-based access control that easily and securely scales to enable flexible cloud computing.An IAM Role can perform any of the permitted functions defined in its Role Policy. Just as you can permit actions, you can explicitly deny actions. This policy language enables significant combinations of access controls to create highly flexible yet highly secure infrastructure."
attributes.name: EC2 Instance IAM Role Not Enabled
attributes.resolution: "To resolve this issue, log into your AWS Management Console and follow these steps:In the Services menu, click the IAM service.In the left pane, click on Roles.You will see the Create New Role button near the top of the main window, click on it to create your first IAM Role.Enter a friendly name for the role.Click Continue.In the Select Role Type window, you will have several options from which to choose:\r\nAWS Service Roles—Permits EC2, CloudHSM, Data Pipeline, or Opsworks to call other AWS ServicesCross-Account AccessIdentity Provider Access—For Identity FederationSelect the policy option that is right for you and proceed to complete the setup by following the prompts.The most common setup is the AWS default that allows for EC2 access to AWS Services. For most, this is a great way to realize flexible, yet secure, EC2 access enabled for your instances. Select this when you launch EC2 instances to automatically inherit these permissions."

attributes.description: "When an EC2 instance is not part of any configured ELB or ASG in the region it may be a risk as a single point of failure.This signature will skip instances that are associated with an ELB or have auto recovery enabled."
attributes.name: EC2 Single Instance Does Not Appear to be Redundant
attributes.resolution: "We encourage using an ASG to automatically replace an EC2 instance in the event of an issue. AWS provides this automated service free of additional charge.If the instance is intentionally single, we suggest configuring auto recovery in the event something does happen to mitigate the impact."

attributes.description: "One or more EBS volumes appear to not be attached to an EC2 instance. EBS volumes often persist after an EC2 instance has been terminated. We recommend regular review of these volumes, since they can contain sensitive data related to your company, application, infrastructure, or even users."
attributes.name: Elastic Block Store (EBS) Volumes Detected and Unattached
attributes.resolution: "Periodically review EBS volumes. Archive them to Glacier, remove the volume entirely, or reattach them if they were inadvertently orphaned.To resolve this issue, first log into your AWS Management Console and follow these steps:From the Services menu, select EC2 . In the left pane menu , click on Elastic Block Store > Volumes.Sort using the \"State\" column and locate the volumes that are not in use.Review the volume information (create date, size, status, etc).Determine if you wish to retain or remove each volume.We recommend taking the time to attach volumes to test instances so you can actively browse the content. While volume names and tags are often generic, the data on each volume will be highly informative as to the volume's previous use."

attributes.description: "This signature detects and sends an alert if your ELBs are vulnerable to the POODLE SSLv3.0 vulnerability. You can read more about this vulnerability at the official Google security disclosure here: : http://googleonlinesecurity.blogspot.com/2014/10/this-poodle-bites-exploiting-ssl-30.html.The POODLE exploit allows the plain text of secure connections to be calculated by a network attacker, thus exposing previously-thought secure connection transactions to a malicious entity."
attributes.name: ELB POODLE Vulnerability Detected (CVE-2014-3566)
attributes.resolution: "To resolve this problem, follow these steps:Log into your AWS Management Console.From the Services menu, select EC2.In the left pane, navigate to Load Balancers.Choose your Load Balancer.Click on the Listeners tab. Click Change in the Cipher column. Ensure that the radio button for \"Predefined Security Policy\" is selected.Select the most recent policy from the dropdown menu.Click Save to apply the settings to the listener. Repeat this step for each listener that is using HTTPS or SSL.Repeat for every load balancer servicing HTTPS/SSL connections in your accounts."

attributes.description: "An ELB is not configured to use secure ciphers for session encryption. Applying the current predefined security policy will provide an up to date SSL configuration for your HTTPS/SSL listener. "
attributes.name: ELB Secure Ciphers Not Configured for Session Encryption
attributes.resolution: "To resolve this issue, follow these steps:Log into your AWS Management Console.From the Services menu, select EC2.In the left pane, navigate to Load Balancers.Select the load balancer you wish to reconfigure, and then select Listeners.Locate the SSL-enabled listener ports in the list that appears.Under the \"Cipher\" column, click Change to enter the configuration menu.Select Predefined Security Policy.Choose the most recent AWS policy available.In the event that one of the ciphers listed in this policy becomes compromised, you may select the Custom Security Policy option and uncheck the cipher in question.For more information, please see AWS ELB Security Policy."

attributes.description: "Your SSL certificate is within 45 days of its expiration date. If it expires, many clients will refuse the connection with your service."
attributes.name: ELB SSL Expires in 45 Days
attributes.resolution: "Please begin the process to renew your SSL certificate with your provider, and plan for an update during a convenient maintenance window."

attributes.description: "You have less than 5 days remaining before your SSL certificate expires."
attributes.name: ELB SSL Expires in 5 Days
attributes.resolution: "URGENT. Initiate expedited process to renew your SSL certificate with your provider, and plan for an update during the first available maintenance window. If one is not scheduled before the certificate expires, move the next maintenance forward or schedule an additional window.Failure to renew your certificate and replace it before it expires may cause disruption in your service and adverse user reactions."

attributes.description: "Your SSL certificate is within 90 days of its expiration date."
attributes.name: ELB SSL Expires in 90 Days
attributes.resolution: "Please begin the process to renew your SSL certificate with your provider, and plan for an update during a convenient maintenance window."

attributes.description: "One or more of your Elastic Block Storage (ELB) instances supports potentially vulnerable Ephemeral Diffie-Hellman (DHE) in its configuration.DHE was the first public key exchange protocol and is still commonly deployed on ELBS and web servers. We recommend updating your ELB SSL Negotiation Policy configuration to remove DHE ciphers that are potentially vulnerable to 1024-bit and lower breaks"
attributes.name: ELB Supports Vulnerable DHE SSL Negotiation Policy
attributes.resolution: "To resolve this issue, follow these steps:Log into your AWS Management Console.From the Services menu, select EC2 .In the left pane, navigate to Load Balancers.Select the load balancer you wish to reconfigure.Select Listeners.Locate the SSL-enabled listener ports in the list that appears.Under the \"Cipher\" column, click Change to enter the configuration menu.Select Predefined Security Policy.Choose the most recent AWS policy available.In the event that one of the ciphers listed in this policy becomes compromised, you may select the Custom Security Policy option and uncheck the cipher in question. We recommend following the best practices contained in the AWS ELB Security Policy."

attributes.description: "Global permission to access the well known administrative TCP port 3389 (RDP) is detected in a security group."
attributes.name: Global Admin Port Access - RDP (TCP Port 3389) Detected
attributes.resolution: "Reduce the permitted IP Addresses or ranges allowed to communicate to destination hosts on TCP port 3389.We recommend utilizing the static office or home IP addresses of your employees as the permitted hosts, or deploying a bastion host with 2-factor authentication if this is infeasible. This bastion host becomes the only permitted IP to communicate with any other nodes inside your account. If you must permit global access to TCP port 3389 (RDP), then you may disable this alert to silence it.For more information on Ports, see AWS: Ports."

attributes.resolution: "Reduce the permitted IP Addresses or ranges allowed to communicate to destination hosts on TCP port 22. If you must permit global access to TCP port 22 (SSH), then you may suppress this alert.If more information on Ports, see AWS: Ports."

attributes.description: "Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is currently permitted on a global scale to your AWS infrastructure. ICMP is used by devices to communicate error messages and status. ICMP is a useful troubleshooting tool, but can also be used to exploit or disrupt operations of systems."
attributes.name: Global ICMP (Ping) Access Detected
attributes.resolution: "We recommend you restrict ICMP solely to systems, services, and IP addresses within your control and not globally allow it.For more information on Ports, see AWS: Ports."

attributes.description: "Global permission is granted to a security group to access the well known services UDP port 445 (CIFS)."
attributes.name: Global Service Port Access - CIFS (UDP Port 445) Detected
attributes.resolution: "Best practice dictates restricting access to service ports solely to known static IP addresses within your control. Reduce the security group access list to contain only known hosts, services, employees, or office static IP addresses is advised. If you must leave port 445 (CIFS) open to the Internet, suppress this alert to silence it.For more information on Ports, see AWS: Ports."

attributes.description: "Global permission to access the well known services TCP port 137 (NetBIOS) is detected in a security group.NetBIOS is a legacy protocol developed in the 1980s for very small networks. NetBIOS over TCP/IP allows legacy applications to utilize NetBIOS to communicate over the Internet, however it is a security risk to modern networks. Web services are particularly at risk."
